dt: {bc}to initiate or habituate especially by giving a foretaste
{bc}to clothe or cover with or as if with flesh
{bc}to make fuller or more nearly complete

dt.t: museums {wi}fleshing{/wi} out their collections with borrowed works

shortdef: to initiate or habituate especially by giving a foretaste
to clothe or cover with or as if with flesh; broadly : to give substance to —usually used with out

dt: {bc}the soft parts of the body of an animal and especially of a vertebrate
{bc}the parts composed chiefly of skeletal muscle as distinguished from internal organs, bone, and integument
{bc}the condition of having ample fat on the body
{bc}flesh of a mammal or fowl eaten as food

dt.t: the spirit indeed is willing, but the {wi}flesh{/wi} is weak

dt: {bc}facts or details that provide substance to something

dt.t: Her careful documentation puts the necessary {wi}flesh{/wi} on much that has been merely speculation …

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}flǣsc{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}fleisk{/it} flesh and perhaps to Old English {it}flēan{/it} to flay {ma}{mat|flay|}{/ma}
shortdef: the soft parts of the body of an animal and especially of a vertebrate; especially : the parts composed chiefly of skeletal muscle as distinguished from internal organs, bone, and integument
the condition of having ample fat on the body
an excessive growth of granulation tissue

dt: {bc}to provide more information about (something) {bc}to make (something) more complete by adding details

dt.t: You need to {it}flesh out{/it} your plan with more details.
She {it}fleshes out{/it} the characters in her novels very well.

shortdef: to provide more information about (something) : to make (something) more complete by adding details
